The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters. This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. Provide your answer with these fields. - suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code. It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated. DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments. \n"; static const char body_footer[] = "\n" "\n"; pos = 0; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_header, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header)); pos += MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header); for (filler_pos = 0; filler_pos < (body_dyn_size - (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_header) + MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer))); ++filler_pos) { body_dyn[pos + filler_pos] = body_filler[filler_pos % MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_filler)]; } pos += filler_pos; memcpy (body_dyn + pos, body_footer, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (body_footer)); } else { /* Fill the body with binary-like content */ size_t pos; for (pos = 0; pos < body_dyn_size; ++pos) { body_dyn[pos] = (char) (unsigned char) (255U - pos % 256U); } } } return ! 0; } Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. explanation:
The MISRA rule targets uses of the <string.h> routines that may access beyond the bounds of the referenced objects. The code fragments selected are the points where data is copied/filled into the dynamically allocated buffer body_dyn using memcpy or indexed writes driven by a loop bound that uses unsigned arithmetic. These need investigation because they can cause out-of-bounds accesses when body_dyn_size is smaller than the expected header/footer/filler sizes or when the subtraction in the loop bound underflows (unsigned wrap).

Other code fragments were not selected because they do not directly invoke string.h functions or perform indexed memory writes that could overflow: create_response_object itself does not call memcpy/memmove/etc.; usages of MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ with string literals (e.g., for tiny_body and other static strings) compute compile-time sizes and are safe for those literals; the binary-fill loop (body_dyn[pos] = ...) uses a simple pos < body_dyn_size loop and thus is bounded; the calls to MHD_create_response_from_buffer(_static) / MHD_create_response_empty are API wrappers that do not themselves perform string.h operations in the shown code. Therefore only the memcpy calls and the filler loop were flagged for further investigation.
